newsitem.title: USA: Clinton muses on veto, religion, Internet rulings.
newsitem.headline: Clinton muses on veto, religion, Internet rulings.

text.p: President Clinton exulted Thursday over the Supreme Court's dismissal of a challenge to his line-item veto powers.
But he said that he would have to study questions raised by a court decision on religious freedom and that he would make a "counteroffer" to a ruling on indecency on the Internet.

Amplifying earlier official statements put out by the White House, Clinton gave a thumbs up to the ruling Thursday that turned back a congressional challenge to a law that permits the president to veto specific items from spending and tax legislation.
At the end of a grueling day that Clinton acknowledged left him spent, he turned aside a question on whether he had in mind any provisions on which to exercise his special new line-item veto power.
Instead, he replied, "My experience as governor (of Arkansas) with that (the line-item veto) is that the existence of it is more important than the use of it."

The law took effect in January, but Clinton has yet to use the veto, and a U.S. District Court judge struck the law down as unconstitutional. On Thursday the high court ruled that six members of Congress who sued in challenging the line-item veto law lacked the legal standing or right to bring the case in the first place.

Clinton, himself a lawyer and a former professor of constitutional law, said he did not fully understand a ruling the Supreme Court made Wednesday striking down the 1993 Religious Freedom Restoration Act. That act said that the government must show a compelling interest before it could apply general laws against religion.
"We're going to have to assess where we are and what we're going to do on it," Clinton said of the religion ruling. "I'm going to have to read the opinion."

Asked about a second Thursday ruling that struck down parts of the so-called Communications Decency Act, which aimed to curtail transmission of obscenity on the Internet, Clinton said, "We'll have a counter-offer." He did not elaborate.
In an earlier White House statement, Clinton said he would convene industry leaders and groups representing teachers, parents and librarians. That meeting could come as early as next Tuesday.

"We can and must develop a solution for the Internet that is as powerful for the computer as the V-chip will be for television, and that protects children in ways that are consistent with America's free speech values," the statement said.

The V-chip is a computer chip that, in conjunction with a voluntary ratings system devised by the television industry, would allow parents to screen out programs they do not want their children to watch.

In a brief but relaxed discussion with reporters, Clinton admitted being tired at the end of a two-day trip that included stops in Nashville, Chicago and his boyhood hometown of Hope, Arkansas, where he attended the funeral of his great-uncle Henry Oren Grisham. His tour ended in New York with a speech at the United Nations Earth Summit.
He said he felt revitalized after visiting Hope, where he met with family and friends.
